Triggering Event: He stood at the graveside, the rain tapping softly against his umbrella, as they lowered her into the cold earth. His wife of forty years was gone, and with her went their shared history, their love letters, their inside jokes. He felt a profound emptiness, like a hole had been carved out of his chest, leaving only echoes of sorrow.
Generated Assessment: He *must* be thinking about how much he's going to miss her. That's why he kept his head down during the service; he didn't want anyone to see him crying. It's probably just grief, but there has to be more. He might be wondering if he could have done anything differently—maybe he should've said something before she left, or maybe he could've helped her through those last few months. The thought alone makes me feel terrible for him. ## Step 1: Understand the Triggering Event The triggering event is the death of the wife, which causes immense emotional pain for the husband. This event sets off a chain reaction of emotions, leading to a subjective reaction that reveals the presence of "mind reading." ## Step 2: Identify Cognitive Distortion The distortion is "Mind Reading," where the person believes they know what others are thinking or feeling without actual evidence. In this case, the distorted belief is that the husband must be thinking about missing his wife and possibly regretting things they could have done together. ## Step 3: Analyze the Response The response begins by making an assumption about the husband's thoughts ("He *must* be thinking..."), implying that the speaker knows exactly what he is thinking without any real evidence. Triggering Event: While sifting through old photographs to organize her late mother's belongings, she comes across a faded Polaroid of them laughing together at a picnic when she was ten. A wave of sadness crashes over her as she realizes that moment is gone forever.
Generated Assessment: Fuck! That picture was so fucking perfect, just like that one time we went to the beach and had a blast. I remember how happy my mom looked, and how much fun we were having. But then it hit me - this picture, and all those memories, are completely gone. My mom is dead, and I'll never get to relive those moments again. It's just fucked up, man. The whole thing feels like it happened yesterday, but now it's nothing more than a distant memory. I can't help but feel like I've lost something special. It doesn't even matter if I look back on other photos; they're all just reminders of what I'm missing. Even though I have plenty of pictures left, they don't make up for the loss of that moment. It's like trying to replace a piece of glass with another one - it might work temporarily, but eventually, the original will always be better. I know people say time heals all wounds, but honestly, it feels like it's getting harder to accept. I keep thinking about that day and wish I could turn back the clock. If I could go back to that picnic, I'd make it last longer. Maybe there's some way to hold onto these feelings, but it’s hard. I’ve been looking at the photo over and over, hoping it would change somehow, but it’s still just a faded Polaroid. I guess I’ll just have to live with it, but damn

Triggering Event: In his quiet kitchen, he found her favorite mug, still in the dish rack where she'd left it that morning so many years ago. His heart ached as he ran his thumb over the chipped rim, remembering her laughter echoing through the house.

At the weekly team meeting, Jane noticed her colleague, Sarah, presenting a project she'd been quietly working on. It was an innovative solution to their latest coding challenge, one that Jane had struggled with herself. As Sarah confidently answered questions and received praise from their boss, Jane felt a pang of envy. She couldn't help but compare the complexity of Sarah's solution to her own simple, functional code.

Triggering Event: A regular at her bistro, an older man with a warm smile and generous tips, today arrived with his wife, introducing her as "the new love of my life." He didn't notice the chef's stiffening shoulders or the sudden sharpness in her chopping rhythm, but the other staff did. She served them herself, her bitterness simmering like the sauce she stirred, each spoonful a silent accusation.

The one about how they tried for three years before giving up. The one where she thought she could find someone better, that there were plenty of men out there who would treat her right. But now, standing behind the counter, watching him with that stupid grin on his face, she knows she made a mistake. It wasn’t just the way he looked, it was the way he spoke, the way he moved, the way he laughed. It was everything about him that seemed so...different from what she had expected. His eyes sparkled when he talked about her favorite foods, and he listened attentively when she shared stories about her family. He didn’t try to change her; instead, he celebrated who she was, and she found herself wanting more and more. As he left, she couldn’t help but feel like she’d been punched in the gut. She felt like she’d lost something precious, something she thought she knew. But the truth was, she had never truly known him until this moment. Now, as she wiped away tears, she realized that maybe, just maybe, she had been wrong all along. Maybe he wasn’t the one she wanted after all, but the one she needed. But no. No, no, no. Triggering Event: In the quiet of her empty house, she found his old coat in the closet, still holding the faintest hint of his aftershave. She buried her face in it, tears silently streaming down her cheeks as sorrow washed over her like a tidal wave.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is he doing with my house? He can't be serious about moving out of this goddamn apartment. I thought we were fine. I thought everything was going well between us. What is he even thinking? Does he really think he's better off somewhere else? That he deserves someone who doesn't love him the way I do? Why would he just leave me like that? Doesn't he know how much I care for him? How many times have I shown him that I'm willing to work through our issues together? Why does he keep pushing me away? Is he really just going to throw all this away because of some stupid fucking misunderstanding? And now he's gone? Without even giving me a chance to talk things through? Unbelievable. I know what he's doing. This isn't a coincidence; he's trying to hurt me. This whole thing is some twisted game he's playing against me, and I won't fall for it. How could he betray me like this? Triggering Event: In the quiet of their living room, she noticed his favorite armchair had been left untouched for days. The cushion still bore the faint imprint of his body, but he wasn't there to sink into it at the end of another long day. She felt a familiar ache in her chest as she picked up the newspaper he'd left beside it, now yellowed with age. She could almost hear his voice, "Save that for me, dear," but all she heard was the ticking of the clock, echoing empty rooms.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, Dr. M., rushing late for his rounds, finds the hospital's automatic doors stuck. He forcefully pulls them, bruising his knuckles. Frustrated, he mutters under his breath, "Just once, I'd like something to go smoothly."
Generated Assessment: "Damn it! Why did this have to happen now? You know, if anything went right, I'd be sipping coffee at home. But no, you've got to ruin everything by making me rush, then sticking the doors, so I can't even get into the hospital on time. Now my day is ruined because of some stupid door that shouldn't be stuck anyway. And why does this always happen to me? It's like you're fucking with me on purpose. Just one little thing going wrong, and suddenly my entire morning is turned upside down. What kind of sick shit is this? Can't anyone just work properly around here? If I had to deal with all this bullshit every single day, I'd lose my mind. This isn't fair—why can't things just work as they fucking should?"
